summary: This tutorial video guides viewers through the process of exporting and installing a Minecraft mod using MCreator and Forge.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen, followed by a scene featuring a stylized tree logo with the text "NorthWestTrees GAMING" overlaid on an aerial view of a cityscape. The scene transitions to a computer screen displaying a file explorer window with numerous folders and files, predominantly labeled with names such as "AcaciaPath," "BirchPath," "DarkOakPath," and "OakPath," among others. The file explorer window is open to a directory named "NorthWestTrees," and the cursor is positioned over a file named "WoodSpeedPath111." The video maintains focus on this file explorer window, showing the same directory and file names without any changes or movements. The environment remains consistent, with the computer screen and file explorer window being the primary visual elements throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with an upbeat, rhythmic instrumental piece featuring prominent percussion. Following this, a male speaker begins a tutorial, explaining the process of exporting and installing a mod into a 1.14 version of Minecraft. He emphasizes the need for Forge and the Java edition, and advises listeners to read the MCreator EULA, summarizing that while selling the mod isn't allowed, accepting donations is permissible under certain conditions.

events_list.video_caption:
The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying a file explorer window filled with numerous files and folders, each labeled with names such as "AcaciaPath," "BirchPath," "DarkOakPath," and others, indicating a structured directory likely related to a project or software development. The interface is dark-themed, with green and white text on a black background, and the file explorer is organized into columns, showing file names, icons, and possibly file sizes or modification dates. The taskbar at the bottom of the screen reveals that the computer is running Windows, with various application icons visible, including Google Chrome, File Explorer, and Visual Studio Code. The system clock shows the time as 9:41 AM.

The scene then transitions to a different view of the computer screen, now displaying a terminal window with a dark background and green text, indicating the execution of commands or scripts. The terminal window is filled with lines of text, including commands and outputs, suggesting that the user is interacting with the system or running a program. A pop-up window titled "Make sure to follow our End User License Agreement!" appears in the foreground, with a message urging the user to read and accept the terms of the license agreement. The pop-up includes a checkbox for agreeing to the terms and buttons labeled "I agree to the EULA," "Skip EULA," and "Send feedback." The taskbar remains visible, showing the same applications and the time as 9:41 AM, indicating that the transition between scenes is seamless and occurs within a short timeframe. The overall atmosphere suggests a focus on software development or system administration tasks, with the user actively engaging with the computer to execute commands and review legal agreements.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing how to export a mod in a software, mentioning a specific icon that says "export the mod for distribution" and keyboard shortcuts such as Control+E. The speaker explains that the version of the software determines Minecraft compatibility, indicating a tutorial or explanation setting.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a dark-themed code editor with a terminal window open, showing a series of commands and outputs related to a software development process. The user is interacting with a dialog box titled "End User License Agreement," which prompts them to accept the terms before proceeding. The dialog box includes a checkbox for agreeing to the terms and buttons for "I agree," "Decline," and "Send feedback." The user clicks the "I agree" button, and the dialog box disappears, revealing the terminal window again. The user then opens a file explorer window, selects a file named "new_file.go," and begins typing code into the editor. The code editor displays syntax highlighting, with keywords in blue and comments in green. The user continues to type and edit the code, with the terminal window still visible in the background, showing ongoing processes and outputs. The video concludes with the user actively working on the code, with the terminal window displaying various commands and outputs related to the development process.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing the process of reading a EULA, agreeing, and exporting a mod. He continues to describe how to save the mod in a format that people can read, giving it a personal name that includes the Minecraft version and mod version. The speaker adds information about how a properly named file makes it easy for people to identify the mod's details. He instructs the listener to click save and mentions that it will save to a folder, adding that you can click the home icon to save it to the desktop if desired. He concludes the segment by stating that he has covered everything that needs to be done in this particular part of the process.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer desktop featuring a dark-themed interface, with various icons and folders scattered across the screen. The taskbar at the bottom shows several open applications, including a web browser and a file explorer. The scene transitions to a video game simulation, depicting a highway scene with a large black truck towing a trailer, alongside a white and brown station wagon. The environment is detailed with trees, road signs, and other vehicles, creating a realistic driving experience. The video then shifts back to the computer desktop, displaying a web browser open to the Minecraft Forge website. The page shows download options for Minecraft Forge version 1.14.4, with a prominent warning message about ad blockers and a suggestion to support the creators on Patreon. The desktop background remains consistent with the previous scenes, featuring the same highway simulation and various desktop icons. The video concludes with a return to the Minecraft Forge download page, emphasizing the available options and the importance of supporting the creators financially.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker explaining how to install a mod. He sounds instructional, saying the mod is "right here" and specifying the need for Forge. He directs listeners to "Minecraftforge.net," instructing them to choose the appropriate version and download the recommended installer.  After completing installation he mentions the next step will be double-clicking on the installer.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop screen with a background image of a highway scene featuring a large black truck and a smaller car. The desktop is cluttered with various icons and folders, including a prominent "FORGE" icon. A pop-up window titled "FORGE" appears, displaying options such as "Create New Vehicle," "Edit Vehicle," and "Load Vehicle." The user selects "Create New Vehicle," and the window transitions to a "Building Progress" screen, indicating the process of creating a new vehicle. The background remains consistent throughout, with the highway scene and vehicles in motion, while the desktop icons and folders stay in their positions. The video captures the user's interaction with the "FORGE" software, highlighting the steps involved in creating a new vehicle within the program.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker providing instructions, explaining that one needs to click "install server" when setting up a Minecraft server. He goes on to clarify the difference between a client and server version, stating that a client is for personal use, but players joining must install the client as well. A click sound punctuates the explanation as he advises installing the server version if running a server. The speaker then continues explaining to simply click "okay" and it will automatically install the Forge version for your client.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer desktop screen displaying a simulation game featuring a large truck and a car on a road, with trees and a clear sky in the background. The desktop is cluttered with various icons and folders. The Start menu is then opened, revealing a list of applications and games, including Minecraft. The Minecraft Java Edition game is launched, showing a loading screen with characters and creatures from the game. The game's main menu is displayed, listing different versions and profiles, with the option to play highlighted. The video concludes with the Minecraft game interface showing the list of profiles and versions, with the cursor hovering over the 'Profile 1 | 1.4.4' option, ready to start the game.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single speaker explaining that once everything is set up, it'll only take a few seconds, depending on the computer's speed. Speaking in an informative and somewhat technical tone, the speaker then directs the listener to the Minecraft launcher, specifically to the "installations" section where a Forge version should be present. The speaker mentions that one is currently unnamed, but contains "1.14 Forge" and the Forge version number. The speaker transitions to saying that they'll make a new profile using this version.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying the Minecraft Launcher interface, specifically the "Minecraft Java Edition" section. The interface is organized with a list of profiles on the left side, each labeled with a version number, such as "Profile 1 1.4.4," "Profile 2 1.4.4," and others, indicating different Minecraft versions. The right side of the screen features tabs for "Versions," "Snapshots," and "Legacy Snapshots," with the "Versions" tab currently selected. The "Latest snapshot" option is highlighted at the bottom of the profile list. The interface is set against a dark background, with the text and icons in contrasting colors for visibility. The taskbar at the bottom of the screen shows the Windows operating system, with various application icons visible, including the Start menu, File Explorer, and other programs. The time displayed on the taskbar is 6:44 AM. Throughout the video, there are no significant changes or movements, maintaining a static view of the Minecraft Launcher interface.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a speaker, likely male based on tone, instructing someone: "So to do that, we're going to click on the little plus icon up at the top of the list." His tone is instructional and clear. Then he continues with "and there."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a user navigating through the Microsoft Windows operating system to create a new installation of Minecraft. Initially, the user is seen on the 'Create new installation' screen, where they have filled in the 'Name' field with 'Minecraft' and selected the 'Version' as 'Lunar release 5.1.2.3'. The 'User installation' field is set to 'Default', and the 'Resolution' is set to 'Custom'. The user then opens the Start menu, types 'minecraft' into the search bar, and selects the 'Minecraft Launcher' from the search results. Following this, the user opens the 'Run' dialog box, types '%appdata%', and presses Enter, leading to the opening of the 'AppData' folder. The user then navigates to the 'Roaming' folder within 'AppData' and selects the 'Minecraft Launcher' folder, indicating their intention to modify or install Minecraft. Throughout the video, the desktop background remains dark, and the taskbar at the bottom of the screen displays various application icons, including File Explorer, Google Chrome, and Minecraft. The video captures the user's methodical steps in setting up Minecraft on their computer.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with someone speaking, explaining that they're going to go to their ".minecraft" folder. The speech is informational and delivered in a neutral tone. Then, the speaker describes how to access the relevant folder by typing "%appdata%". A brief sound occurs during the speech but its type and contribution is unclear.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen with two open windows. The top window displays a "Create new installation" dialog box with fields for "Name," "Password," "Version," "User Installation," "User Settings," and "Resolution," all of which are left blank. The bottom window is a file explorer showing a directory path "C:\Users\username\AppData\Roaming\minecraft\profiles" with various folders and files, including "1.13.2-Forge," "1.13.2-Forge-12.18.3.2511," and others. The user navigates through the files, highlighting different entries, and eventually selects a file named "1.13.2-Forge-12.18.3.2511." The video concludes with the user opening a new window titled "Minecraft Launcher," which displays a loading bar and the text "Loading Forge Profile." The desktop background is dark, and the taskbar at the bottom shows various application icons, including Google Chrome and File Explorer.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing creating a 'profiles' folder for Minecraft, suggesting it's good practice when using mods and different versions of the game. He describes the process of creating a new profile, including naming it in a specific format, followed by copying its path.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying the 'Create new installation' window for Minecraft Java Edition, where the user selects the version '1.14.4' and proceeds to the 'Minecraft Launcher' window, showing the 'Minecraft Java Edition' logo and a 'PLAY' button. The scene transitions to a desktop view with a Minecraft game window open, showing a character in a cave with a sword and a green creeper. The user navigates through the game's main menu, selecting 'Singleplayer' and then 'Mods,' revealing a list of installed mods. The video then shows the 'Minecraft Launcher' window again, with the user selecting the '1.14.4 Forge Profile' and opening the 'Minecraft Launcher' settings, where the user adjusts the 'Controls' settings, specifically the 'Walk Backwards' key from 'Left Control' to 's.' The video concludes with the user navigating to the 'Options' menu, highlighting the 'Chat Settings' option. Throughout the video, the desktop background features a road scene with vehicles and trees, and the taskbar shows various application icons and the time as 9:45 AM.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker detailing a technical process, mentioning specifics such as "Minecraft Forge" and "1.14.4" in a neutral and instructional tone. He then transitions to discussing options and versions for the process. There is a shift to describing how to play and generate files with the profile. The speaker continues, mentioning exporting a mod after completion. The discussion moves to configuring settings, including details like chunks, disabling music and auto-jump. There's a remark about setting controls, disabling bobbing and maximizing certain settings, concluding that "that's good". The segment closes with the speaker preparing to exit the game and drop the mod into the mods folder within the same profile.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer desktop screen displaying a game simulation of a highway scene with a large truck and a car. The desktop is cluttered with various icons and folders, and a file explorer window is open, showing a file named '1.14.4 Forge 28.1.0'. The user navigates through the file explorer, selecting the file, and then closes it. The Start menu is opened, revealing a list of applications, including Minecraft. The user then opens the Minecraft launcher, which shows the Mojang logo and a loading bar. The Minecraft game interface appears, displaying the 'North's Path Mod' information and options. The video transitions to the Minecraft main menu, showcasing the 'Singleplayer' option highlighted, with the game environment visible in the background, featuring a grassy landscape with a house and a cobblestone path. The text 'Minecraft Java Edition' and 'Full of stars!' is prominently displayed at the top, indicating the game's title and version. The bottom of the screen shows the version information 'Forge 28.1.0, Minecraft 1.14.4, HRF 20190823143755, 3 mods loaded', along with copyright information 'Copyright Mojang AB. Do not distribute!'. The video concludes with the user seemingly ready to start playing Minecraft in singleplayer mode.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, who appears to be giving a tutorial by describing technical steps. He mentions being in the same profile that was set up for a "forge," and then, there is a brief glitchy sound, reminiscent of a "bleep." The male speaker then continues with the description, noting that "your mods are in here and then you're just going to drop your mod into the mods folder." After this, the speaker mentions relauncing Minecraft, and states it will take a second to load up and check if the mods are working. Finally, he notes how to test if the mods are working by clicking on mods and seeing if the file is loaded and says if that is not the case, you might want to re-export and make sure the correct version for forge is installed. To conclude, he proposes clicking on a quick single-player world.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screen displaying the 'Create New World' menu from a video game, where the player is prompted to enter a world name, select a game mode, and choose additional options. The game mode selected is 'Creative,' which allows unlimited resources, free flying, and instant block destruction. The player then clicks the 'Create New World' button, and the screen transitions to a loading screen with a progress bar indicating the world generation process. Once the world is fully loaded, the player is presented with a first-person view of the game environment, showcasing a vast landscape with a clear blue sky, floating islands, and a body of water. The player navigates through the game, exploring the terrain and interacting with the environment. The video then transitions to a promotional screen for 'NorthWestTrees Gaming,' featuring a stylized logo and a background of a desert landscape. The final scene shifts to a different game, displaying a first-person view of a player in a rural setting with a map and various game controls visible on the screen. The video concludes with the 'NorthWestTrees Gaming' logo superimposed over the game scene, emphasizing the branding of the gaming channel.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a person speaking in a casual tone, discussing selecting "creative" and confirming a mod is working. This leads into a general explanation, including "I have a new tab, so it's right here, that's perfect". Concluding with a thanks to the listener for watching. Transitioning to a short music section that could be classified as a backing track or incidental music, featuring a synthetic sound.
